subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... I can see that elaborating structure /sometimes/ might impact speed. On the other hand, elaborating structure can also illuminate the darkness and focus
messageBody:
On Tuesday, September 23, 2003, at 1:16:11 PM, Jim Dixon wrote:

> On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, Ron Jeffries wrote:

>> There seems to be some agreement in the thread, around "use as few
>> comments as necessary and no fewer."

> Uhm, well ...

> Most people reduce the number of comments by using longer names and
> elaborating program structure. While this might seem free, it isn't.
> There is a direct cost in terms of program size and execution speed.

I can see that elaborating structure /sometimes/ might impact speed. On the
other hand, elaborating structure can also illuminate the darkness and
focus attention on where to make things fast.

I myself wouldn't avoid defining a method to make things clear. I might
then wind it back in /if and when/ a performance measurement showed it was
necessary.

My experience is that a huge percentage of the tight code we write just
because it's more efficient is wasted effort. My practice is to write clear
code, and then optimize it where it needs it, reducing clarity if I must.

> The August 2003 issue of the Communications of the ACM focuses on program
> compaction and has a lead article "Extracting Library-based Java
> Applications". This concerns software developed by IBM researchers to
> reduce the size of Java code. One of their tools minimizes the length of
> names where possible (it's not possible where a name is part of a
> published interface). Using this and other techniques they typically
> shrink Java code by well over 50% for a small one-time cost in terms of
> computer cycles (it takes about 4 minutes to process 3.8 MB of code on an
> 800 MHz PC).

I can see how some Java systems might increase the size of the code by
including non-public names, but it seems somewhat of a bug to do so as a
matter of course.

If short names were really valuable, I might write with readable names and
then precompile the software down to short names. We once did that with a
whole operating system, although our purpose was obfuscation, not
efficiency.

> There is a reasonably reliable relationship between code size and
> speed. Less than half as many bytes typically means software that
> runs more than twice as fast.

This is news to me, and I can think of counterexamples, such as unrolling
loops, or hard-coding table lookups, which typically increases both size
and speed. Have you some references regarding the speed/size relationship
and how it varies?

>> There seems to be some disagreement, far less specific, around how
>> many that might be.
>>
>> I suspect that there's some sharing and learning that might help
>> someone learn something. One way to do that would be to present a
>> little code that one thinks is down to minimum comments, and see what
>> others can do with it to make it need fewer.

> Sure, but bear in mind the cost of using long names and an expanded
> class hierarchy to replace comments.

> I'm not saying it should be forbidden. I do it myself all the time.
> But nothing is black and white; there are always tradeoffs.

Yes. I suspect that I think the tradeoffs favor clear code more than you
do, but that could be because I don't work on the same kind of code.
Conceivably, I might have a few different tricks.

> However, if you are suggesting that documentation should always and in all
> ways be minimal, I have to disagree outright. Someone using software
> should not have to refer to the code to understand how it works. On the
> contrary: there are strong arguments for never looking beyond the
> Javadocs. If that sort of documentation is missing or is unreliable, the
> cost of using software soars.

Javadocs to understand HOW it works? I wouldn't think so. What it does, how
to use it, yes. But how?

In any case, unless you mean we should produce more documentation than we
need, I think we must agree on "minimal" but perhaps not on just what
"minimal" means.

> Is this relevant to testing? Yes it is. Where code is underdocumented,
> the poor guy who inherits it often must resort to exploratory testing,
> to understand what the code actually does. This is extremely expensive,
> a waste of programmer time.

Yes. And when code is well-tested, the tests serve as compilable,
executable commentary. They can't replace all comments, but they can do a
better job than other comments. Or so it seems to me ...

Regards,

Ron Jeffries
